The book starts with Cindy grieving her sister Penny's death. Cindy always idolized her sister because Penny took care of her after their parents' death. Penny's death is ruled a suicide, but Cindy later finds out that Penny had a wrongful death suit against the NYC Department of Transportation on behalf of their parents. She also knew that Penny had a sexual harassment case at work that was later dropped. The family attorney is convinced that Penny's death is the result of foul play, and not suicide, so he suggests hiring a private investigator to look into Harvey Goldman, the investment broker that swindled her dad, sexually harassed her sister, and got away with it.Cindy sets out to trap Harvey Goldman by changing her identity. She later develops feelings for him, and he claims to be a new and improved version of himself. Cindy is torn, but in the end, Harvey is sent to jail for embezzlement, and then sends Penny a letter suggesting that, if she wants to know who killed Penny, she should come talk to him in person.He tells her he loves her, and pretty much suggests that the only way she'll get any closure regarding her sister's death is to contact him personally. How arrogant!

I thoroughly enjoyed this story of love, forgiveness and second chances. If you have not already read Chloe's Revelation, then buy the version of this book with Chloe's Revelation included.  Without reading it first Saul's Story won't be as meaningful.  The author does a good job developing the characters and their Amish lifestyle.  The book includes many Amish/German words which add authenticity to the reading experience.  She includes three vocabulary list throughout the book, but many of the words and phrases are not included.  Some you can figure out from the context of the sentence/chapter, but many you cannot.  I found this to be very frustrating!  I wish she had put the meaning of each word/phrase in parentheses after each word.  This is the first book I have read by this author, and will read more of her books.
summary: Great Story of Love and Forgiveness

Alex is a very sweet & innocent woman. She works hard to take care of her family & is trying to figure out a way to earn money for her dad to have a heart transplant. In walks Jayden he is a billionaire many times over and is recently broken up with his long term girlfriend. His sister is getting married & he doesn't want to deal with his grandmother's matchmaking so he decides to hire a girlfriend. When his friend Peter sets him up to meet Alex she accidentally dumps tea on him & becomes very flustered. Seeing this Peter knows what needs to happen so he convinces he  that Jayden is gay so she will agree to this. As you can probably guess Jayden is a very eligible bachelor & all the girls want him. Alex isn't really in their league but can hold her own! I loved the story, it had suspense & a sweetness you don't always see.

This book was a very good book to read. A guy named Jayden has to find a pretend girlfriend to take home to his family for the weekend to keep his matchmaking Grandmother from finding him a wife. A of his named Peter decides to help him out by fixing him up with Alexandra. She needs money to pay for her Fathers heart transplant operation. If he doesn't get it soon he could die. Jayden is a billionare and he offers Alexandra money to be his girlfriend for the weekend. Alexandra is hesitate about taking the money, but she knows it's the only way to save her father so she agrees to pretend to be his girlfriend to save her Father's life. Jayden and Alexandra goes through some good times as well as some bad ones. Jayden did have a prior girlfriend, but they broke up before he could introduce her to his family and that's the reason he has to hire a girlfriend. I won't go into the details of why they broke up. I'll leave that part for the reader to find out. I'm not going to tell you every thing because that would ruin the fun of reading a good book. I really enjoyed reading this book, especially all of the experiences Jayden and Alexandra go through with his family. Great book and I would highly recommend it. If you love romance books, then this one is for you. I think you will enjoy it. I know I did. I would love to read more of this author's books.

I've been looking forward to Dante's book since we first met him..... I love dragons and a dragon shifter is a particular favourite of mine!!!One of the things that really draws me to this series is the uncertainty around what each of the 'lightening struck' will become... Nadie is no exception ~ and her new found paranormal species is very interesting!!We've witnessed Nadie's mixed feeling and emotions towards Dante in the last few books and our favourite dragon hasn't made any moves to return her affections - finally in this book we see things moving forward for them - but Nadie, Jace and Dante have their work cut out to be together though I have to say, boy, it was worth it!Tangled Innocence is action packed, filled with suspense, treachery and deceit... along with a lot of emotion and red hot passion as you'd expect when you have a bear and a dragon shifter and the one to complete them that they have been waiting years for!If you haven't started this series I would thoroughly recommend you give it a try - and if you have already read the previous books I'm sure you won't be disappointed with this latest installment from Carrie Ann!!!**One scene with the female dragons had me in fits of laughter.... wonder if you can guess what I found so funny?!?!
summary: Another fantastic installment from an great series!!

reviewText: In Second Chance Bride, by Trish Morey, we met Tara, Scarlett Buck’s twin sister.  Almost a Bride by Sarah Mayberry, tells  her story.  All her life, Tara Buck has been the responsible twin.  She never took risks, had a responsible job as a patrol officer at a local police department and was engaged to be married to a history teacher – she had the perfect life.  When she finds out her fiancé is not the man he appears to be, Tara is led to question whether all her safe choices were really so perfect after all.  She decides to let go of her inhibitions and experience things she’s always been afraid of…including her feelings for her long time police partner, Reid Dalton.  On this journey of self-discovery, Tara overcomes her fears and finds the courage to love.
I find it more for people who want to sell things.  It is good, but I was looking for blogging for pain.

The PremiseThe third book in the Big Easy series by Ms. Carr, Bella Carper has crushed on Justin and Ned since her first day on the job, but she’s vowed that she would never act on it.  But when Justin and Ned offer a no holds barred night at their BDSM club, Bella has trouble fighting her feelings and reaching for what she wants.The GoodI didn’t know that this was the third book in a series, but it didn’t hinder my enjoyment. Ned and Justin are hot and the menage scenes are sexy.  This is a novella, but the setup is done in a way that I could buy into their ongoing attraction and there’s enough detail to at least set up their spectacular little one nighter.The BadThe story is short, and as a result, there’s not alot of character development.  The plot’s pretty thin and Bella’s protests were irritating after a while, though understandable.The Bottom LineIf you’re into menage stories, and just want a real quick read, this works. I would check out more from Ms. Carr in the future.
I thought this book would be way hotter than it turned out to be. I love ménage stories...this one is good just didn't have the heat I was looking for.

This book is just plain fun.  Light is a strong female character and Ryker is, in one word, hot.  The dialogue between the two of them is smart, sexy, and many time laugh out loud funny.  This book reminded me a little of a Lindsay Sands paranormal, but hotter.  Be warned, there is a big cliffhanger.Please note the author was kind enough to gift a copy of the book in return for this honest review.

I was always looking for the right diet and I found it.The Mediterranean Diet is founded on the idea of eating fresh whole foods as a means for maintaining your health rather than dieting for a specific body type. The Mediterranean Diet is not about limiting yourself at all, it’s all about maximizing the flavors in your food by creating tons of variety in your dishes and enjoying your meals with friends and family. Equipped with a 7 day starter menu this plan is useful for anyone who doesn’t have a plan for eating healthy and is willing to try something new. This plan is a return to the basic principles of eating real food that comes from the earth and is filled with nutrients rather than processed with chemicals. If you’re reading this you will likely find this book helpful in expanding your options in the kitchen and at the table by keeping it simple.

The Mediterranean Diet is a heart-healthy way of eating, rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, beans, nuts and legumes. Healthy eating doesn't mean you have to eat boring, tasteless food and the delicious recipes in this book are evidence of that.  I like how this book is easy reading and includes a 7 day starter menu so any reader can make a healthy change to diet beginning today. I am a big believer in healthy eating and the big league benefits that come along with it - better health, more energy and vitality - and am glad to have come across this book so I can recommend it to clients.

I have enjoyed all of Joseph Flynn's books, including this one.  I would recommend them as good, fast paced stories where the good guys win.  I love the creative solutions to serious social problems like limiting private funding of  political campaigns, lobbyist influence and gun control.  Don't we all wish for a president like Patti.

I give this book 4 1/2.(but rounds up to 5) This book is a continuation of Book 1 Songbird.  Tara is now waiting for Riley While he is away in the Military. And Cole is still being a a great friend and a man ho. Not sure what it is about Cole’s character But I love him.. he super sexy and his bad-boy ways are just delicious.Cole tries so hard to change his ways.. You can see how much he is in love with Tara. But Tara is waiting for Riley to come home because she told him she would marry him. This book offered me frustrations for Cole, romance, super sexy Bad-boy , and some super sexy scenes.The Question is? Does she end up with Cole or Riley? I can’t tell you that because again I am left wondering whats going to happen next. This is an awesome book . But you do need to read book 1 to fully appreciate book 2.

Book 2 in this series again did not disappoint although I'm not sure how I feel about the love triangle that has developed. What a cliff hanger. This book has many creative breakfast sandwhich recipes that are easy and quick to make.  Which is exactly what I am looking for in the morning, a simple but tasty breakfast that is  a great change from the same boring peabut butter toasts. I made the pear and brie panini, it was so delicious.  Can't wait to make some more recipes from this book like the brunch panini or the turkey reuben quesadilla. You don't have to make these recipes only for breakfast, they are great at any time of the day.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of legal thrillers in general, but what I loved most about Predatory Kill was the very topical, economic angle it took. Predatory lending gone bad indeed! The corruption it presents will ring all too true in the ears of the politically minded, but with added twists, turns and compelling courtroom-style drama.Realistic dialogue, an apparently acute knowledge of the judicial system on behalf of the author, and a sympathetic cast complete the package for Predatory Kill, which could easily be made into a major Hollywood feature. This was one page-turner I couldn't put down from start to finish.
summary: A legal thriller with a topical economic twist

reviewText: 5 Star Review of The Forever Trilogy by Sandi Lynn AuthorI absolutely love this Trilogy!  Connor is so alpha and sexy (even though at times I wanted to knee him in the junk).  Elle is so strong, smart, creative and a great female lead!  The characters are so beautifully written and conveyed such emotion.  The attention to the fine details that make the story are amazing and not overwhelming.  I really like Sam and her appearances in the books.  She could be potentially a player in a spin off.  Denny is so loveable and I enjoyed the major role he played in the lives of Connor and Elle.  Let's not forget Mason and Peyton...those 2 are what best friends are made of.  I was sad to see the series close, but it was ended so wonderfully that it left me happy as well.  Sandi did such a terrific job with this series!  A DEFINITE must read!

So this was seriously awful.  I had seen the individual books when they were first released and since they was such a mixed bag on reviews I decided to skip it.  However, when the trilogy was on sale for $0.99, I figured I would give it a try.  I wish I had skipped it.  This was truly the worst (and laziest) writing I have ever read.  The heroine was completely selfish, immature and downright annoying.  I did not get the appeal whatsoever.  While the first book was truly awful, the 2nd book was worse.  You get the male's POV, but it is literally word for word with the same tired line included over and over . . . "damn that smile."  LAZY WRITING!  Meanwhile the 3rd book was just plain ridiculous.  Do not waste your time on this series and definitely don't waste your money.
summary: This was truly the worst (and laziest) trilogy I have ever read

reviewText: Forever black though pretty cliche in the rich guy romance section did hold my attention. It was a good quick read of mindless pleasure.However when I got to Forever you it was as if I was rereading the same book in the past tense. So many chapters were word for word that it pissed me off. The way in which she wrote the second book did not in any way appeal to me. Forever us was okay. It tied up loose ends so they could live happily ever after.Bottom line:Book 1: Pretty goodBook 2: CrapBook 3: Alright
I thought the book should have stopped after the second book. This should not have been a trilogy.

Connor and Ellery will take you through laughter, frustration, anger, tears but most of all a love that runs so strong and deep that nothing will or can shake or separated them. You will feel all of these feelings with them and then celebrate a life of love that we all can dream of! What a beautiful and tender story! Thanks Sandi!

reviewText: Dee has made a short but thorough book on how to use outlines to make writing your book so much easier.  The tools she shares, many of them free & and with links to them in her book, give you few excuses to delay putting her information to good use.

OMG what can I say about this series that has become one of my absolute favorites.......First off, I am loving the growth of Chloe's character! She has changed in the last six months since taking down the Talon Building and her boyfriend Drew and the rest of her family are worried. Worried she's hardened to much, to quickly but Jennifer Wright showed me that Chloe has built a wall and is very much feeling all kinds of emotions. She chooses not to show them. She wants to be strong and take charge of ending what has begun. I think she will open up eventually and let everyone know that her motivation is Love. Pure and simple. For humanity. For her family. I think it's what's keeping her strong, not the endless training or her hate for these monsters.The new discovery in this installment leaves the story open to so many possibilities. Mrs. Wright is keeping me on the edge of my seat through this series. I got to the end and was left with my mouth gaping. It's getting so exciting!!!! I think I'll be stalking her endlessly for the next one. Lol.I highly recommend this story. As well as the two before this Love and War (#1) and Taking Talon (#2)
summary: Got my fix & now a withdrawal until the next one.

reviewText: The whole time I was just a  confused as Meg.  Crazy and exciting read.  I could get enough. It's kept reading hoping for answers.  Still not so sure about Nancy and the diary. David aka Ryan was crazy and then what was with Elizabeth and Frank.

C Ray Calhoun had me with the Hillbilly and hound dog story. Talk about driving the point home in a way that is as entertaining as it is enlightening, that one story made the difference to me. I got to admit, I really like the writing style that Mr. Calhoun employs with this book. I can appreciate what he went through and admire his tenacity in staying the course and really like his commitment to helping others.This book give a very upbeat and encouraging message that the power of positive thought does indeed bring the desired results one wants. The tips and advice, while rooted in common sense, does provide a road map, if you will, on how to stay on track and keep the faith that perseverance is a key along with focus, illustrated by this quote from the book, "One becomes poor that has a slack hand but the hand of the diligent makes one rich."C Ray Calhoun delivers in a simple down to earth manner that will touch just about everyone who reads this book. After reading this book, I feel like he is an old friend that I have known my entire life and feel enriched by his insightful message. For the money, you can't go wrong with this one. Yep, I do believe that this book can be of significant benefit to the reader. In closing this review, I'll borrow one more quote that sums it up rather well, "The power of believing is unbelievable" and I do believe that is the point to the book. Thanks Mr. Calhoun for a wonderfully written book!

Have battled depression for most of my life and learning to cope with depression has been the hardest. Great read on things you can do to easily cope with and alleviate the depression that so many suffer from. A few of the techniques I had never heard of, so will look into them. Anyone looking for help, this is a good read.

In A Wicked Game by Evie Knight, Tori is at the top of her game career-wise, but on the personal side she is still looking for her happily ever after. So when her friend Ariana offers her an invitation to an exclusive online dating service, she decides to use it.Jack accepted the invitation he was given by his friend to Elite, an online dating service. What he didn’t expect was to be set up with the one woman he cannot forget after her stunt in college. Now he has to decide leave or stay and finish what they started.While Jack decides to stay, it’s not for usual reasons any other person using Elite would. No, he plans to get payback on her. And so he leaves her in a very embarrassing situation herself.Which is how we begin the story, and why Jack and Tori begin doing all kind of crazy thing to get payback and one up one another again and again. But we all know that much feeling cannot only derive from their humiliation, and so begins their journey to their own HEA.I love this series, it’s HOT, it’s fun and it’s a fast read that I want more every time. I cannot wait to see who is next and what will happen.
summary: A Fun, Fast and Really HOT Read

reviewText: WOW! I didn't know where Angela could go with this spin off story but I definitely wasn't prepared for this! It's like she is re-writing the ending to the "Pieces of Lies" and teasing us with some freaking awesome secrets!With tales of secret societies, rich and powerful men and women, good vs. evil and then throw in some steam....."Fiendish Play" is born!James Riley, *SWOON**, is the perfect blend of everything we all wanted in our first love. A senior college art student, James is caring, loving, respectful, extremely intelligent and at first site, totally enamored with Anais Ashton.Anais is stuck in a dark world of pain, secrets and betrayal. She wants nothing to do with it but unfortunately like so many, the lives we are born into have a way of taking a front row on the life we are forced to lead.When James and Anais get together, the fireworks fly in more ways than one. As the secrets begin to unravel, there were be more twists and turns than a roller coaster! If you have read the previous series, there will be overwhelming moments of shock and awe. If you are new to Angela, be prepared to get lost in the suspense and drama that her novels deliver every time!The subtly with which Angela delivers the steam is remarkable. You're going along, buried in the suspense and BAM! there will be this scene so hot that curls your toes! If you are looking for a different kind of romance, this is the author you need to be reading. On a side note, I think I am falling in love with Australia and not just its hot men. So many great writers are popping up from the Golden Coast and I feel a need to relocate! BAHAHA!
summary: OMG! I freaking love Angela's suspenseful novels!

reviewText: We continue along with Logan & Ava as she figures out if she wants to do this whole “muse” thing. The thing is…..her painting has never been so good and well….creative!Logan is writing like never before and the creative juices are flowing. They agree to the muse thing and the HOT affair continues. Will an actual relationship form out of this? Will they fall in love? And what about keeping things secret? Will they get caught?

I really like this book because it combines so many interesting features. It is easy to follow, it is full of interesting information, and it also have a lot of beautiful photos. SEASONAL SEAS: How do Seasonal Seas Work? is a great source of information for children, but not just them. I also learned a lot about the topic. This is a book for a whole family and I am sure that each member will learn something new about seasonal seas and creatures that live in them. At the end of the book there is a quiz where one can check what have he/she learned from the book. My family have a great time playing that quiz.
summary: Interesting read about how do seasonal seas work

reviewText: TR was very candid in this interview. It revealed TR's drug use and some interesting pointers to writers on how TR goes aobut writing and what he focuses on as most important.
I very much like Tom Robbin's books and admire his imagination and use of words. However, this was a boring interview.

Book Worms was gifted this book from the Author for an honest review.We gave this book 3.5 stars, this is book 2 in the Desire Series and it is not a standalone.This Review was left by Leigh a Book Worms Reviewer. Thank you Leigh.Heated Desire ReviewHeated Desire picks up where Tainted Desire left off. Kylie Jenkins is introuble. Her boyfriend, Cameron Conner, got a call from her and heard everythinggo down. His roommate, who is also his sister's boyfriend, has kidnapped Kylie.When Cameron gets to the scene of the wreck, he isn't sure Kylie is alive. Hefinds that she has survived but is in a bad condition and must go to thehospital. She is unconscious for several days.When she wakes up Cameron is there with her. Cameron leaves the rest of theracing season to take care of her until she is better. Kylie feels that sheneeds to stay independent and doesn't want to interfere with his dream job as aNASCAR driver. These two must figure out where to compromise and where torespect the others wishes. Right now the only place Kylie wants Cameron to takecontrol of her is in the bedroom... or where ever they decide to get it on.Comprises are made, new relationships are formed, but the past will come backto haunt them in the end.I give this book 3.5 out of 5 starsI still think the characters in this book are great. Kylie is a veryindependent woman and has bounced back well from all she has gone through.Cameron is still an awesome and caring boyfriend. This book also gives morestory of Kylie's best friend Courtney Conner.I like the fact that, in some parts, as soon as I thought I knew what wasgoing to happen it turned out totally different than I expected. I can't saywhat it was without revealing some major spoilers.Even though there were some things I didn't expect at all, there were somethings that just seem to be in every book right now. Our main character ends upin the hospital unconscious for days. There's a jealous boyfriend in a bar thatbeats up another guy for being around his girlfriend. There's a few more, butagain I don't want to give any spoilers.In the first book I was okay with all the sex going on between Kylie andCameron. They were a couple getting reacquainted after years apart. Now, it justseemed like way too much screwing was going on. I'm pretty sure Cameron'sfingers were turning into wrinkly, soggy fingers from being submerged in Kylie'ssuper soaking lady parts. I'm also certain that Kylie has acquired TMJ from allthe attention she is giving Cameron's manly member. I just found myself skimmingthrough the steamy scenes towards the end. I would have rather had more storygoing on, but that's just me.Over all, I did like the book, and it was worth reading in continuation of theseries. I plan to read the next book in the series as soon as possible. I haveto know what happens to Kylie and Cameron.
summary: If you like tons of sex this is the book for you! Great book sequel book in the series!

reviewText: Dance Like Nobody’s Watching is Book 3 of the Summer Lake series, one that has been anticipated by anyone who has read Books 1 & 2. Missy and Dan’s story has been evolving slowly since Love Like You’ve Never Been Hurt. I give it a solid 4.5 stars.Overall, I liked the story. I kept waiting for a big conflict that never quite materialized, and that is why I couldn’t quite give that last half star. I thought a couple elements could have been a little stronger, a little more edgy or angsty, but none of the conflicts seemed to really threaten to keep them apart. But part of me really liked that. It was a love story about two people working out real-life type issues to make a relationship work. I very much liked that Missy and Dan talked to each other and didn’t have any of those annoying misunderstandings that drive me crazy! It makes it a bit fluffy, so readers who MUST have angst, and want to bite their nails worrying whether or not there will be a Happy Ever After may not find this fits the bill.As with the other Summer Lake books, all the characters in Dance are well drawn, and the repeat characters hold true in all three books. I thought Missy’s independent and stubborn streak was very realistic, and in her case I actually admire that she just didn’t jump in and swoon so that Dan would take care of her. I found Dan to be almost too perfect, but I liked him. He wasn’t too over-the-top beefcake and he seemed very believable to me.Random musing:So Chance, Michael, Smoke and Laura, and Leanne and Ryan.... Each of these characters are very strongly drawn and I’m assuming their stories will be told in other books. There are very strong (and I’m assuming deliberate) hints about them, especially Chance and Michael, and I am left with a desire to know what their stories are, and who they are going to end up with. I’m also anticipating Ben’s story, coming down the line at some point. Summer Lake has potential to continue for at least three if not four more books.I read an advance copy of this book.
summary: Summer Lake just keeps getting hotter!

Great series about genetically altered humans. These hybrids have been imprisoned since birth, but a fire gives them a chance to escape the lab where they were created. Of course none of them are prepared for the outside world. I loved reading about how Mace comes to terms with his freedom. He's a bat shifter, and he's afraid of getting caught, so he hides in a cave. Mace saves a lone caver, but then ends up putting the man in more danger. The physical attraction between the two men is intense, but there's definitely emotion as well. The connection grows stronger and the sex scenes are hot! This is the second book in a series, but it works as a standalone. Science fiction, shifters, and Manlove—a great combination!

I have read a few shorts from K.M. Tepe in the past and I liked them, but I am honestly blown away by what she has done with Slaughtertown Circus. I can't really think of a book that I would call both fun and flawless until now. This was hilarious, but also had so much depth to it.The pacing was stellar. It grabbed me and didn't let go. I am also very impressed at how many dimensions there were to the characters. The physical aspects of the clown race were thorough and amazingly creative, given more than enough relevance to make them believable.The author has achieved the perfect mix of everything I enjoy in a book, without it ever being tedious or overdone. Frankly, the book kicks a$$. If you read bizarro at all, you need to read this one!
summary: This may end up being my favorite book of the year....

reviewText: Slaughtertown Circus is a winner on all fronts; pacing (something was going on constantly), characters (some of them were so frickin' hilarious!), storyline (creative), and believability.This read had me laughing out loud and re-reading lines. I loved the clowns!A very imaginative read that I suggest you check out. I'm sure you'll enjoy your time in Laughtertown

Amazing. Brilliant. One of a kind.  All words to describe Jamie McGuire's writing.  This book had it all.  Small town, mean girls, hot guys, love, heartbreak, tragedy, Chevy trucks, DQ, and a major twist, just to name a few.  People can be cruel, but Erin Easter was able to somehow make it through the years of bullying and still stand tall with her shoulders back and chin up!  Weston Gates is one of those good guys that realizes he's let things go on for way too long and it's never too late to try to change it.  The twist you never saw coming allowed these two to find comfort in each other and realize maybe that's where they were supposed to be all along.  Can't wait for the next book!!!!

reviewText: Jamie has done it again. She has gotten me lost in a story that couldn't have been any better. Erin is a bullied girl, Weston is the jock, popular. I've waited for a story like this. Call it a twist of fate. Erin is bullied constantly by 2 other Erin's in her small hometown. One day she decides to stand up for herself, somehow giving Weston the courage to stand up to his friends when he's had enough of their bullying of an innocent girl who was given a crappy hand of cards at birth. A tragic accident reveals some "mistake" that throws her whole world into a tailspin and she doesn't know which way is up. I admire this girl, even though she's fictional. And bravo to Jamie for the very well written story that has captivated me.

The novella Happenstance was awesome and I think all teenagers should read it!  You get what you give in live and Karma is a real thing.  You fall in love with this group of people and want to know more of their story.  There is a valuable lesson to be learned from the three Erins.  Be kind and just because you don't seem to have it easy in life doesn't mean you should give up!
Such a wonderful story and I cannot wait for the next installment. Jamie McGuire has done it again! She always creates such realistic characters that you feel their joys and pains.

reviewerName: Because Two Men Are Better Than One! "NicStar"
reviewText: Love Lessons Learned was typical K.C. Wells and reminiscent of the cross-over series Learning to Love - this story focused on John, brother to Evan from Learning to Love: Evan & Daniel.It is very similar in style which was perfect because I was looking forward to some nice and sweet characters. It was also nice to get the little peak at Evan and hear how the boys from the previous series were doing.In this story, John is venturing out into his first real job, as the teacher at a school in a disadvantaged area. John has just acknowledged his own sexuality and has no experience with a man but he falls heavily for Head Teacher, Brett.Brett, at 33, has just discovered he wants more out of life than the anonymous sex filled holidays he takes a few times a year. He wants a real relationship but the fact John is the new teacher he is mentoring takes him out of the equation for Brett.In this story, they first need to take the steps to get together, face the ramifications of a relationship at work and deal with a number of other obstacles thrown their way. Along the way there are good friends, aggrieved co-workers, and some dramatic moments. There is hot sex and there is romance. The characters are sweet and nice and emotional.This was a 4 star for me, mainly because I needed a good dose of sweet with happy endings.
summary: Sweet and emotional - drama and romance.

reviewText: I've looked at some of the other reviews and many of them give good information about the book, and of course there's the blurb, so I'm going going to just add a couple of thoughts and leave it at that.The stories in the collection are horrendous and beautiful. They all revolve around the end of the world we know, yet are hopeful. Sending a group of explorers into the unknown as a sort of human vanguard. They must go into hibernation and therefore leave everyone on Earth behind. They leave, knowing that family members, parents, spouses, even their children, will be long in their graves by the time they wake up. Heartbreaking and hopeful.There is always the notion of a higher purpose and a refusal to let go. The main characters in these stories are thinkers, dwellers, people seeking answers. They find it impossible to leave the past behind but refuse to let it stand in the way of the world as it is, or will be. A woman, alone in the brutal new apocalyptic world meets a man who ends up protecting their most treasured belonging, a notebook filled with memories of life as it was.Jason Gurley has a gift for dialogue. There are no large flowery musings here, just people honestly saying what they think. I have yet to read anything by him that wasn't thought provoking, and even stories with dark subject matter were, in their way hopeful and poignant. At this point he has become one of a small handful of writers that I would buy work from without hesitation. He is that good.

This is a book about Leila Connors who has gone to a romance writers and had her favorite romance author Cheryl Bullard critique her work. The problem is there isn't much that she likes about Leila's writing. So Cheryl invites Leila to the Island of Eden to help her learn about her strengths and her weaknesses when it comes to her writing. During this process Cheryl claims to not only help Leila learn more about her writing technique but also how to search for her story in her everyday life. Leila learns more about herself not only as a writer but as a woman as well. This helps Leila learn what she is willing to give of herself as well as what she is looking for in a man. As Leila learns what she wants and is looking for in a man the hero of her story gets more depth and becomes more engaging to the readers. At this point the only person who is reading her story is Cheryl and this is important to Leila because her option matters when it comes to writing. There are times in the story that you are not sure if the heroin in this story is dreaming it all or if she is really experiencing what she is writing. This book is amazing and I would recommend it to anyone and everyone.

reviewText: "Things are not always what they seem; the first appearance deceives many; the intelligence of a few perceives what has been carefully hidden" ~ Phaedrus...... a bit too deep? O.K., let's make it a bit more fun! Have you ever gotten one of those variety boxes of chocolates? You know, the ones where they all pretty much look the same, but they are filled with a variety of fillings... & they come with that oh so handy little pamphlet ,to let you know which is which...I emphasized the word little, because...imagine that handy pamphlet gets LOST!!! SHOCK HORROR! It's happened to me before, your hand hovers over the chocolates, carefully weighing up which is the most likely to be the caramel centre... you take the plunge & grab the scrumptious square of chocolate decadence, pop it into your mouth, savour that first hint of chocolate melty goodness...your teeth bite into it, in anticipation of the sweet, caramel delight &.... gaaaahhhh!!!! What the Hell!!!! perfumey, jelly-like, sickly sweet turkish delight invades your taste buds & knocks you for six!!!!Right, at this point you are thinking "What the Hell is she going on about?"... trust me, I have a valid point her ;) Ripp, the MC, is 230lbs of tall, bald headed, muscular, tattooed, pierced, brutish testosterone! He bare-knuckle fights! He drives a red 1969 Chevelle SS & rides a motorbike....& he LOVES sex! Basically a walking hunk of "Bad Boy" testosterone!Labelled. Unstoppable. Bad Boy. Simple.The problem is, Ripp... or Michael Allen Ripton... is not so cut and dried, and that is what takes the story from one level to a completely different one! He is more complex... he has values, humour, fears, vulnerability... The scenes with his family were real, there were laugh out loud moments, and when he meets Vee, he allows her to see beyond his carefully constructed image at the man inside, a man willing to change for the right woman..."I think we all have the capacity to change; we just have to want to do it. It's developing the want that is difficult. We become stuck in the routines, so comfortable, so unwilling to take the risk - we just don't see the value in change. Either that or we're just plain uncomfortable with what the change might offer."It turns out Ripp is unstoppable in this respect too! It takes a strong woman though, and I LOVE that about Vee! She is beautiful, but she's also intelligent, a defense lawyer, fearless and unprejudiced... she REALLY sees Ripp... "It was satisfying to get to know a man that was his own person, and didn't comply with what society expected him to be or become."Unstoppable was an unstoppable read for me, it was real, HOT. funny, sexy, HOT, surprising, HOT (Did I say that already?) and romantic, in an unconventional way...Look beyond the surface..."I. Got. This"Unstoppable.

The Terminals has an unusual story line with the Army using/killing terminal patients so the patients can track bad guys in the afterlife and hopefully coerce details about plots that haven't actually taken place yet so they can be stopped. Christine, our heroine (a Lt. Colonel in the Army), made a bad choice getting 11 of her troops killed (apparently there are two other events which went bad, but they weren't described) so she kills herself out of guilt, well almost. It's made clear it was no pansy a$$ed attempt so we know her state of mind. The General comes and talks her into joining the team. I don't want to write more about the plot (though children are taken), because it's what develops that is intriguing, it's better the readers discover it on their own.I can't rate it higher because I thought it needed to be fleshed out more. There are actually two entwined stories Christine's and one of the terminal's. I found his to be confusing and the transfer of knowledge from him to Christine unexplained. One minute he's fighting the bad dead guy, then it cuts to Christine in a chopper trying to save people. We're introduced to other characters who are stock characters because Christine can't be the only one looking for the missing kids. How Christine handles some betrayal left me cold too. I would have thought she'd have responded more and try to be more proactive. Why Christine decided to give something to the family of one of her troops isn't clear either. It pops out of no where. The change in the husband's demeanor too facile.Another reviewer mentions that this may be a series. I guess I'm curious about what happens with the program and the main characters from this point, but it's not something I'm anxious to read, so 3 stars.I received two copies for my honest review: one from the author and one from Netgalley which I forgot I'd requested. So, I was obviously interested in the premise.
summary: Interesting take on the afterlife, needed more

reviewText: I liked it quite a bit.  Great plot, engaging, well-developed characters.  The in-depth look at the religion of gnosticism was well done, but not for the squeamish.  The author handled the various plot threads well and integrated them deftly.  The only reason I'm not giving this 5 stars is that when done, I had no desire to read further into the series.

I believe this story could have potential. Now I'm not a professional writer, but I love to read, and this story description had me interested. Is it Hoth in here, or is it just me?The Superfox is the second "Geekrotica" novella by Ava Lovelace (Nomme de Plume of Delilah S. Dawson, author of the Blud Novels). With nods to Wonder Woman and the Avengers, this scentalizing story is super sexy.Taking place during Atlanta's recent snowpocalypse, Superfox follows Melissa (Lissa) Martin, a Wonder Woman look-alike who works as a project manager at a marketing office. Lissa is a fully developed, strong woman archtype. She's a leader, a trait that scares most guys away. And even though the snow is falling, she decides to stay in the office to finish up an important project. She's not the only one left in the office, though. While roaming the halls, she comes across Mark Ranger, a photographer who is a cross between Thor and Loki in a kilt. Being alone, they get to know each other and indulge in a few choice work-place fantasies.The Geekrotica stories from Lovelace are well-written, fully actualized, indulgent tales. There's no awkwardness, no weirdness. The story and the sex, while fantastically hot, are totally realistic and obtainable.Level Two has been achieved. Now on to Level Three...(originally posted on loebick.com)
summary: Is it Hoth in here, or is it just me?

reviewText: This was a great book. Would buy again

V-Card was a real fun, feel-good book. The main character, Jennifer, heading towards her 21st birthday, is determined to lose her virginity beforehand. Not that she hasn’t had the chance to do so, just that things always go drastically wrong when the time comes. The moment the book started, Jenn’s story had me smiling and as you learn the missed opportunities she’s had to rid herself of her ‘V-Card’, Alicia Michaels provides plenty of moments to laugh at.Fast paced and amusing, there was a lot to love about V-Card. The cast of characters were great to read. I loved Jenn’s best friends Kinsley and Chloe – especially Chloe who was so different from the rest with her high fashion and more expensive outlook on life!The comedy in this book was the best part. Right from the beginning, when we learn about Jenn, her clumsiness and unfortunate incidents, V-Card had me laughing. The first half of the book, when Jenn met Dain and things were just as ridiculous for her as she describes in the first chapter, I loved. It was really entertaining and great just to put a smile on your face. As the book went on, though, as enjoyable as it was, I thought the plot became a bit too predictable and as the focus was more on the romance than the comedy, I didn’t love the second half of the book quite as much.It is a light hearted read though and with a mixture of characters, it’s easy to make relations from them to yourself or people you know. Chloe reminded me a lot of my best friend and I definitely know someone like Dain too. It was refreshing to read a fun, humorous outlook in a New Adult book rather than the more emotional, grim outlook seen in so many and V-Card was simply an entertaining, very enjoyable romantic comedy. I look forward to the next Sharing Spaces book.4/5.*Book gifted for honest review.

Disclosure: I was so underwhelmed by Amazon's free sample that I did not buy the book, and am evaluating it from the sample. Even the title should have been a sufficient warning to me. Here's why.The author uses the device of portraying those who "believe" in global warming as a cult of religious nuts. Cute. Unfortunately, he shows all the characteristics of being an anti-green zealot. It's not long before the reader realizes that Weeks knows enough to throw around key words, but not enough to be in the least factual or truthful.Here's a quote that shows both bad writing and distorted or ignorant "thinking":-"Scientists have been arriving at conclusions of global warming, based on assumptions that are unrealistic. The conclusion arrived by them, is that; the Green House Gases are increasing at an exponential rate. It is known that, water vapor and carbon dioxide are not uniformly distributed, they are distributed irregularly. Yet the effect of water vapor is assumed to be uniformly distributed in most of the mathematical models. When the probability distribution itself is wrong, so would be the mean, variance, standard deviation and whatever can be calculated based on that distribution. Most of these models consider the earth to be flat." [Kindle locations 109 ff.]-There are so many grammatical mistakes in this brief passage, I won't take the time to count or discuss them.Do you have any interest in facts or truth? You won't find much of either in this book. Let me illustrate some of the author's exaggerations, mistakes, or outright lies (choose your favorite characterization)."Green House Gases are increasing at an exponential rate." I have not seen any reputable scientist claim exponential growth in greenhouse gases. True, some knowledgeable people are saying that greenhouse gases are growing faster than linearly at present, and there are perfectly good reasons for this to be occurring. If the author thinks somebody knowledgeable is seriously claiming exponential growth indefinitely, I'd like to see a reference and a context for the statement. OK, you say I am quibbling. Let's move on."Most of these models consider the earth to be flat." This statement is an exaggeration if not completely false. There are a variety of models being used to study climate change. The largest climate models are in fact 3-dimensional and the geometry and inhomogeneities of the earth and its environs are included. Even 1-dimensional modeling is usually done in spherical geometry. I am only aware of a few 0-dimensional models, but even these can be useful under appropriate circumstances. So this is a great sound bite and a very misleading claim.Here's another little passage that has minimal truth value:-"Only average energy components of green house gases are considered in most of the models. Global warming modeling involves interplay of chemical, physical, biological effects with weather. Since they do not behave linearly with weather, the combined effect is ill-represented by mathematical models, which do not account the non-linearity properly." [Kindle locations 115-119]-This proclamation is a multi-target blast, very wide of its targets. First, Weeks objects to using an averaged quantities in a calculation.  In fact, there are many problems in physics that can be solved very well with averaged quantities. Second, he suggests that the models are doomed to inadequacy because not every model includes all processes relevant to the climate problem. He points out that there are even some processes that are not included in any model. Weather itself is one of the factors he uses (erroneously) as an example. Weeks is right that there is no "complete" climate model. However, he is wrong in implying that this means the results of the modeling are too inaccurate to be useful. Many technologies we use have been designed with incomplete, approximate models or with suites of interrelated models. A component of the science of building models is to include the most important factors and to make sure the processes omitted are unimportant in determining the key results. One of the ways of establishing the validity of a model is to make detailed experimental comparisons and to understand the differences between model and experimental results. This is done extensively in the field of climatology. Third, and with the least factual basis of all, Weeks claims that the models "... do not account the non-linearity properly." This is actually a central strength of numerical modeling. If the process is linear, there is no need for much assistance from a computer: a little algebra and a calculator suffices. I can't begin to list in this space the long and successful history of applications of numerical modeling to solving non-linear problems. To name a few well-known examples: computer codes have played important roles in designing atomic bombs, nuclear reactors, and airplanes.The author makes wild allegations of a world-wide conspiracy. With so little knowledge of the field, I don't see how Weeks' claims of fraud and conspiracy can carry any weight at all.If you choose to read this book, you would encounter many more falsehoods than truths. Of course, if you are an anti-Anthropic-Global-Warming zealot or a major conspiracy theorist, you might love it.

reviewText: ****I received copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.****The first book in this series released over a year ago, and as I was reading Hunted, I kept thinking about how the story and characters have developed exponentially since then. Things are coming together and making sense while still giving Kemp much more story to tell. I was no longer scratching my head wondering what just happened. The characters are more fully developed, and I was better able to connect with them. Plus I was just darn excited to find out what was going to happen next!LeKrista has changed in many ways from the first novel, all for the better, while staying true to herself. Her physical appearance has changed. She doesn't spend so much time passed out, and she's much stronger and quite a fighter this time around. I was happy to delve into LeKrista's family history, and as I got to know her and her family, I felt more connected to her in this book than in the first one. When she begins having disturbing nightmares where she's emotionally devastated over and over again, I wanted to kill the person hurting her in those nightmares. I wanted her to get revenge in those terrible dreams. They affected me in a way that made me want to cry for her.In Hunted, I learned more about Pierce and why he's been keeping a huge secret - he's more than human but can't tell LeKrista until they're married and have consummated the marriage. I think this is really interesting and different from other stories. The heat between Pierce and LeKrista has been turned all the way up! In the first book, their relationship seemed blah and lifeless. I wondered why they were even together, so I was excited to see they are passionately in love.I'm still not sold on Roman's character. Different characters have been snarky to LeKrista about choosing to associate with Roman, but really, he came for her to protect her. She didn't seek him out. I don't trust Roman; I think he pretends to love LeKrista because he wants the very same thing as the vampire he created - to use her to take over the world so vampires don't have to hide from humans any longer, not to mention the fact that Vampires, Mages, Werewolves, and Shapeshifters are all vying for power.For the minor characters, I love Tate the most. She's become LeKrista's best friend. Craven, the daywalker, is a new and interesting character thrown into the mix. He's a welcome addition to the cast of characters, and as a daywalker, he differs from vampires in a few ways that I thought were really cool. Lizette is just plain annoying. Shouldn't she blame the one who turned her into a vampire rather than LeKrista? Sometimes her vendetta felt like a repeat of when Perdita was after LeKrista. When it comes to Eddy I'm torn - much of the time I don't like him, but then he'll say or do something that makes me think it's possible I'll end up liking him.I'm still trying to understand the Mages. LeKrista learned she's a powerful Mage. Since she's a Mage as well as her family, why won't the Mages help her? I understand they don't like that LeKrista has been mixed into vampire affairs, but I'd think they would want to help untangle her from all that. Xiomara, who is one of the most powerful Mages and the one who seems to be in charge, has a cold heart. I think she's afraid of LeKrista's power.With time, memories, and events shifting all around, characters with magical powers, and mysteries to be unlocked, Hunted is a book not to be missed.
summary: blew the first book out of the water!!

I picked this book up on NetGalley on a whim.  The cover was pretty good, and the blurb sounded pretty damn good.  By the time I finished the book, I was excited and eager for book two.  I haven't really seen anything that says there will for sure be a book two, but I am crossing my fingers!So this story starts out with Charla, who is a home nurse.  She's just answered a newspaper ad put out by a man who meets her on the porch wearing cowboy boots and a bathrobe - his name is Jack.  He hires her on the spot, and then chapter one brings us to the present. Anyway - back to Charla.  She's pretty okay.  She's not my favorite heroine, but she isn't the worst.  She's a strong woman with a douchey ex in her past, and you know how that goes.  She's working on herself, which is all well and good until Liam steps into play.Now Liam, Liam I liked.  Bartender slash bounty hunter slash all around good guy.  He's ex military and he likes life with a bit of an edge.  He's definitely likable as a character, and by the end of the book I was hooked on him.This book had a bit of the instant chemistry going on in the beginning, and it felt like it was more a part of the "formula" than something that was actually happening.  In fact, there were times that I felt Liam and Charla didn't get along at all, even without any chemistry.  And then the next moment they were very into each other.  But whatever, it didn't kill the story for me.  And actually, as the book goes on, things did begin to gel a bit more, and I was impressed.So anyways, Jack wants Charla to deliver a letter upon his death to Liam.  And that sparks off a ton of events that involve the mafia, lies, and a lot of action. The story moved quick and was exciting. I don't generally read mafia related books, but lately it seems I've been totally into the Irish and mafia.  Go figure.I love the way that family threads it's way through the entire story.  Just when you think you've seen it all, here's another branch on the tree.  And the Irish heritage that binds the guys together plays out very well.  There is one character in the story, who shall remain nameless at this point, who just kind of took off at the end of the book.  He's the reason I am hoping for another book.  It just felt... I don't know, swept under the rug and not really handled well.Anyhow - this book definitely has some different twists, and I would recommend it for a quick read!
summary: Slow Start but really picks up!

reviewText: I was not expecting this book to captivate me so much. I was thrilled it did however. Charla is a great character. She has a troubled past that she is running from but then she meets Jack. Jack changes her life! Charla is thrown into a world of chaos and it all starts with a letter.Liam is one sexy bartender. His past is just as troubled as Charla's. Together they go on a journey that has mystery, love, fear and pain. Its quite the read. I couldn't put the book down. I can't wait to read more about these characters. Liam and his brothers seem like tons of fun.

I absolutely loved the beginning of this book. What a way to meet someone! Charla was given a letter to hand off to a hot, tattooed, muscled up bounty hunter/bar owner.The letter unlocks all this information about Liam's past and Charla is there helping him put the pieces together. Who wouldn't though? The plot develops and intertwines all these previously unknown people to form a deep connection.I thought the book was well written and the story line unravels to make a perfect ending. I read this in a day and a half(I have to work sometimes!). I never lost interest, which is really good since I have a attention span of a goldfish lately.I rate the book a 4.5.

Well, well, well.I just finished reading this baby, and I'm all teeth.  And breathless.  Not unlike the air that tickles the wings of the eagles as they soar high above the mountains, in the final scene.And what can I say about the talent of Ms. Dez Burke, that hasn't been said before?  Very little.  But I can talk about her use of visual, gustatory, olfactory, and kinesthetic imagery.  I can talk about her use of humor.  Property of Flint?  Now, that is hilarious; I'm still chuckling at the thought.  And I can talk about the romance between Flint and Kendra, that starts in Safe House, the first book in the series (get your copy if you haven't done so, as yet) and which grows and cements itself in this story.Yes, the sex scenes are peppered throughout the story, but Liberated is much more than an erotic read.  I learned about the care of animals, not just dogs or cats that we read about in every other book, but about animals that one may not even give a second thought.  It's the first time I read a romance that touches on the care of squirrels, and hawks. This also hints at Ms. Burke's care for such creatures, for all creatures in fact, great or small.And I got to learn about MC subculture.  Who wants to be labeled an 'old lady'?  Apparently, many a Sweet Butt, or an aspiring one. To be called such is not demeaning. I never knew that holding such a title is an honorable thing!  Wow!Liberated is certainly an excellent installment of the Steel Infidels series.  There is love, laughter, drama and suspense.  It also highlights the plight of underage girls who are used as mere pawns.Of course, I continue to look forward to reading more stories in this series.  I still would like to see Jesse get his own story, because he's been through a lot.  I would like to see Flint's youngest brother, Sam, settle the heck down.  And I would like to see the Liberators get their just desserts.Liberated is certainly another excellent tale, written by an exceptionally talented author.Don't waste another second.  Get your copy!  It's less than a buck.  And when you've read it, you'll be pleased to know, it's more than a good investment.
summary: ...another excellent tale, written by an exceptionally talented author

Out of all of the book series I have from the time when we had to travel to a store to purchase an actual physical book to the current digital age of downloading directly to a Kindle, iPad or Nook to have the written pages in our hands within seconds, Krista Lakes' Kisses series has become one of my all-time favorites.  With each story she writes, they always contain characters (both main and support) who are not only extremely likable but also draw me into their lives feeling as though I am a close friend.  I no longer pause to read the synopsis but go straight to the 1-click button to purchase it without a second thought.  When I became aware of her newest novel, Sandcastle Kisses, I of course jumped at the opportunity to read it.Isabel (Izzy) Baker is a marine biologist working and doing research in Key Island in the Caribbean who agrees to moonlight one night as a bartender for a private party.  Izzy never anticipated the possibility of anything more than an opportunity to earn extra money.  That is until she meets Noah, a tourist visiting the island with whom she is assigned to work.  Although she feels an attraction to Noah, Izzy has been burned by tourists in the past so continues to remind herself to keep her distance knowing he will be gone in only a few days.  But as the evening draws to an end, Izzy struggles with the uncertainty that she may not be able to resist his charm and wit, not to mention the fact that he is gorgeous.Noah is actually not a bartender but a rich and powerful business man who was asked to attend the party being thrown by an old college friend.  Upon meeting Izzy, Noah is engulfed into her spectacular world of marine biology and research and is unable to let her go.  But when Noah's world of business and Izzy's world of marine research meet head-on, will their love and passion continue to encompass their hearts or will it be washed away?From the inception of this story, I was drawn into the lives of both Noah and Izzy.  Not surprisingly, Ms. Lakes has again taken pen to paper (figuratively, of course) and written an enjoyable and entertaining story, and hot and sexy one as well.  As always, I found myself struggling with my self-control to keep from flipping to the last chapter on my Kindle just to put my mind at ease and ensure that I would be given the happily-ever-after ending that I am always hoping to find.Once again Krista Lakes has wowed me with Sandcastle Kisses.  Although it is part of her Kisses series, it can be read as a standalone novel.  This book tells a delightfully lovely story, and if you are like me and love Ms. Lakes' Kisses series, I would recommend you not let this one pass you by.  But even if you have not yet had an opportunity to read any of Ms. Lakes' stories, Sandcastle Kisses will beguile and gratify anyone in search of a sweet and romantic tale of finding love.

In "Sandcastle Kisses" we meet Isabel Baker a marine biologist who is moonlighting as a bartender on a beautiful island, this is where she meets Noah, the charismatic billionaire who gets under her skin and sweeps her off of her feet. As their relationship develops their professional lives come into conflict making them question if they really can make it work and if love really does conquer all.The writing of this story was exceptional, she described the island setting so well it made me feel like I was there with the characters. I loved the determination of Isabel. She's a determined and driven woman who isn't afraid to go after what she wants. Noah is plain sexy as sin; he's the type of hero every woman dreams of having in her life. They chemistry was built up nice and the love scenes were incredible.Another great novel by Krista Lakes.

The billionaire love story..the kisses..This Krista Lake series are great. Noah and Izzy  meet one night,  tending bar...She is a marine biologist and Noah is very rich guy, but is he happy? Sweet story..

I found the writing style to be indistinct and there were some clichéd phrases such as 'it was chaos', but it was very easy to follow and will definitely appeal to youngsters. I was unsure of the opening which would have been better depicted as an action sequence rather than a conversation. (In writing you have half a page to grab the reader.) Also I found the dialogue to be a little basic, but I do not think the writer was going for deep and complex. There is plenty of action and imagination on display and Evolution: A Short Story achieves its goals. A fair score would probably be 3 and a half stars, but you can round it up to four if you are a  teenager and a sci-fi fan.

reviewText: Having loved "Surrender (Alien Warriors)"- the previous book to this one, I was sure I would also love "Commander's Slave" and Sue did not disappoint. When Betsy Carson ran, making Fiona Lockhart take her place in marrying a Kall warrior, I wanted to know what happened to the real Besty. I so thoroughly enjoyed the dramatic story of Betsy's experience after she was found, the story that makes up this book. The scene on the slave auction block had me covering my mouth to keep my excited gasps in. I adored Lanzo and Edek for their vastly different personalities. Lanzo's caring for both Betsy and Edek was sweet and I loved how he plotted to fix things. As the relationship spun and burned between Edek and Besty, I started to ponder the happily-ever-after that I was sure Sue had put at the end of her book. I loved it. Loved the drama followed by the exquisite happiness. I so hope some day that Sue writes mores delicious spanking romance crossed with intriguing science fiction.
summary: I want more sci-fi and romance from Sue Lyndon! This is a great book, great world!

reviewText: 4.5 of 5 starsFor original review see The Prism Book Alliance Blog onlineI had a bit of reviewer’s block concerning this book. It is not a reflection on the book, far from it, just an explanation as to why it has taken so long to get the review written. Some reviews come more easily than others. This book was an interesting read. It did not go where I expected it to go, but I loved every minute of the ride. Stone broke formula, both “romance” formula, and patterns he had set with the first two books in the Uniformity series (Compromised and Damaged). You, also, don’t expect to like the main character as much as you do. He is an ex-con, after all.You first meet Dylan Hoss in Damaged. He is a model prisoner and comes to the aid of correctional officer Zane Davis, who is being railroaded by a prison gang and prison officials. I was intrigued to see just how Dylan was going to get his Happily Ever After, being a prisoner and all. I do not often go for the prisoner as the MC, but Stone proved me wrong with book 1, so I decided to give it another try. I enjoyed this book even more. It is my favorite of the series.I found tears pricking my eyes and my heart strings tugging for Hoss when he loses Joey. I found myself yelling at the author for that, as well. I found myself profoundly confused by the pairing of Dylan and Keegan. Yes, Keegan was hot, but he was no Joey. I found the characters once again surrounded by awesome friends. I loved Maggie for her unwavering support of Dylan and Al for his unwavering love of Maggie. I found myself wanting Dylan to make it for the long haul. I was immensely happy that Stone found that HEA for Dylan without taking any undue liberties.

A short (30 pg), helpful, common-sense guide to parenting a child with Asperger's, I picked up free on Amazon. When I was mentoring autistic teens (about 10 years ago), I could have used a guide like this to help me train my student learners. I saw much of the behavior described: repetitive actions (hand washing), focus on numbers (for a student learning data entry), lack of social skills (reminding my student workers to say hello and goodbye), and observing the physical as well as emotional distance they put between themselves and others.  I really liked the section on seting boundaries and helping the child with a routine. If you have a child or know of a child recently diagnosed, this would be a great introduction for you.

And this book... Omg.  Ugh.If you haven't read the book, and love the series.  PLEASE DON'T READ ANY MORE.***SPOILER ALERT***I was so upset when Dan died!!  He was the best part of the whole series.  I didn't care for Andi and Will together.  I felt that I didn't get to really know Will and he was just a background character, and felt that Dan and Andi had more time together.

For some reason that escapes me, while I'm not a fan of the rock star romance, I love sports romance. Both center around some sort of celebrity, both have tons of skanky fans all too eager to sell their souls for a few intimate moments with the star, then you get the egos and sense of entitlement. Why one works for me and the other doesn't is a mystery. I think Sliding Into Home's hero Greg, may hold a bit of the answer. And it comes down to perception. Mine, his, the fans, heck the world in general. The whole story is based on Greg's perception of himself, his father, his relationship with Jenn, and how he wishes to be perceived as well. Am I getting to Zen? Ahhh, well, I'm in a mood.In what was basically a lighthearted, fun sports romance with a thread of serious undertone, I of course decide to pick at the thread. While Greg is determined to step out of the shadow of his father and be his own man, everything he has done to this point in his life has sabotaged his efforts. He is certainly headed in the right direction now, but he still has a chip that's weighing him down. Enter Jenn.Again with the perceptions. She at first perceives Greg as a spoiled, entitled playboy. She looks deeper and adjusts. Yaaay! Buuuut....... she plays into Greg's perception of her as the lawyer/stripper. It made for a truly fun read. Watching the characters grow not only into a couple but into better people. So you can take what you want from Sliding Into Home, a lighthearted romance with hot sex and warm fuzzies, or a study in how we feel about others perceptions and how it effects our own. Either way it is totally worth the time and money. I'm very pleasantly surprised at how much I got out of Arlene Hittle's book. Great job, Arlene!
summary: Putting a Zen Spin on it

OK, I must tell y'all this book as all of Rachel's books was fantastic.  However, Rachel warned me I may not be happy with this Episode.  THAT was an understatement!! I spent half of the book scared have to death because of the very close calls and the other half crying my eyes out!! Oh and the end???? *dirty look at Rachel* prepare yourselves ladies because you WILL be pissed!! Rachel said she "feels bad about it." hmmm...... I don't call her the Queen of Cliffhangers for nothing!!Ok let's discuss this Episode.Page and  Reagan are still forced to live with Kane and his crazy mom, clinging to the fragile  hope that Hendrix will come rescue them soon. Reagan begins to realize that her line of fear and hatred for Kane, is slowly melting into admiration and comfort. She would never walk away from Hendrix but while watching Kane work, she daydreams about the possibility of having met him in a zombie-free world. (At this point I was literally screaming at my iPad) "Snap out of it Reagan!!!!" No worries though ladies, this little uneasy alliance doesn't last long.....The night's tranquility is shattered when zombies attack the house, breaking windows and doors to get at them.  There are WAAAAY too many close  calls for your heart in this Episode!! With the overwhelming number of zombies overflowing into the house, Reagan feels her sanity slipping away and when someone gets hurt she snaps!Now it's up to Kane to save the household while keeping the zombies at bay, luckily he has a plan.....but will it be enough to save a life and restore Reagan 's mental stability?This Episode was SO hard to read and then to have to watch Reagan fall apart like that made it so much worse. She's usually very strong and the glue that holds everyone else together. She was so broken and full of self doubt. It was interesting to see her lean on Kane for help and HE was tender and sweet!?That's the silver lining in this Episode, through the pain, gore and horror Rachel pull back Kane's rough (and HOT) exterior and let's us inside. He has dealt with physical and emotional  trauma far beyond his years. Does this excuse any of his past behavior?? Um heck no!! BUT I like how Rachel put a little seed of doubt in my head about him, will she do the same for you??Now Rachel, the ending!!!?? WHAT ARE YOU DOING TO US???? My husband told me he won't buy me a new iPad if I break it and I need to stop doing that!!! He just doesn't get it!

That is what kept going through my head over and over while reading this episode. What the heck? I understand that what happened is important to the plot line, but really? Was that necessary? That was super messed up in a very entertaining but horrible way.I do not like Kane. I have said it before and I will say it again. In my mind there is nothing redeemable about him. I do have a little sympathy for him but how could Regan? It is his fault that they are in the predicament they are in to begin with! Everything that happened in this episode is his fault. How could Regan forgive him so quickly? I am sure that mass murderers have *some* redeemable qualities, but that doesn't mean they deserve a pass for their mass murdering tendencies. Kane is psycho and he needs to be gone and out of Regan's life.As for the rest of the story all I can say is what the heck. I don't want to give anything away, but it went somewhere I never expected it to go. I can't wait to see what happens next but I need some happiness. Like a wedding. With the right man.

4.25 of 5 starsFor original review see The Prism Book Alliance Blog onlineVy Aleknow is the equivalent of the alpha in his Hawk flock. He came out to his parents in his teens and apart from a narcissistic grandmother everyone offered him kindness and support. He strongly believes in the myths and destiny of a shifter and is patiently waiting for his mate but is terrified at the thought of living his life alone or worse still his chosen mate will be a womanWhen he first smells then meets Robert Cimino all his senses are overwhelmed. This gorgeous man who is only passing through his small town is a bear shifter and his mate. The more Vy sees of Robert the more confused he becomes and he can’t help but wonder why this big bear of a man isn’t drawn to him by their mating bond.The stress and worry that Vy has placed on himself over the whole mating thing has left him lacking in compassion when it comes to other members of his Ket. This only increases when he meets Robert and discovers that the bear shifter actually refuses to shift…ever!  Vy doesn’t understand this and his ideas are so ingrained he can’t see a way of them ever being together if their mating bond is not completed.Robert is of a very different opinion and believes it is how the man feels about the other person that is important and not the animal. He is so far removed from his animal side that all he feels is fear when he think about the bear inside of him. He wants Vy to see him for what he is and not what he believes he should be. He is also terrified of what his bear will do should he ever release him.With or without being mated the two men are very strongly attracted to each other and the sex is hot with a taste of D/s.For their relationship to work they will be both have to open up to sides of themselves that they are afraid to show and even if that happens will Vy be enough to keep Robert in one place and cure his need to never put down roots or stay in one place. If you are a fan of either of these authors or of shifter stories this one is for you!

Miss Pippa Welby, is the daughter of a wealthy tradesman.  Lucas Alexander, the ninth Duke of Arlington asked her to marry him.  She refused.  Now he had 10 days to convince her differently.  Thus ensues the antics of both Pippa and Lucas.  I found this book to be a good book.  I like humorous situations, and this was one.  The proud Duke of Arlington and the determined Pippa.  I loved the cat and mouse chase and the verbal contest between them.  Just when things might be working out for them, Pippa discovers an alternative motive for Lucas’s desire to marry her.  Can she get over this betrayal or are they fated to go their separate ways?  I recommend this book for a cute, light read.  Kate writes the characters with such a light hearted way, it is a joy to read.

A sweet, fun, and thoroughly entertaining romance, How to Lose a Duke in Ten Days was a wonderful read. I really enjoyed reading this lovely novella.Pippa was a great heroine. She was determined to to things on her own terms, refusing to bow to the demands of others. She was clever, though oddly unconcerned about her reputation, and her antics brought a lot of fun to the book. I thought she was lovely.Lucas seemed like a domineering jerk at first, to be brutally honest. But, as the book went on, we see why he acted the way he did and that there was a whole lot more to him than what he showed. Underneath all that strict control, he was very sweet, protective of his loved ones, and determined to ensure his family's fortune after his father squandered it. I really liked him. He was rather adorable.The romance was lovely. Pippa and Lucas were great together. I wasn't really feeling it, though, because Pippa spent most of her time focused on defying Lucas and Lucas spent most of his time trying to keep control. But, I thought it was sweet that, despite all that, their feelings for each other still grew. Not to mention the sizzling chemistry between them. Overall, I thought they were a wonderful couple.The plot was well paced and I was kept interested the entire way through. This book was so much fun to read, just to see the crazy things Pippa did to prove a point. I really enjoyed the story and the ending was lovely.How to Lose a Duke in Ten Days was a wonderful historical romance novella. I really enjoyed reading this sweet, fun, and utterly charming book. Romance lovers, if you want a quick, sweet read, then this is your book.*I received a complimentary copy in exchange for an honest review
